title: Will Haiti hold run-off presidential elections as scheduled on 24 April 2016?
preds: I am forecasting based on the general news reports and gjp consensus.

The odd part is that while the CEP has insisted for weeks they will not be holding elections this weekend, they've also not made the official legal announcement to postpone. Until they sign that legal order, the elections are still scheduled. It's a screwed up situation, to say the least.
CEP says it will not create new crisis in Haiti
Lowering forecast from already dismal 1%. Authorities are saying they "never really promised elections on 24 April" [1] and that they "won't even have a timeline before the end of May" [2].

Reuters reports that the newly appointed head of the electoral council said that "it is clear that the elections won't take place on April 24", but without giving a revised date for them to be held. The chance of election-related violence will likely increase unless a new date is quickly selected and steps are taken to ensure security and demonstrate transparency and fairness in the process.
海地动乱不断，并无多大概率能进行选举

"It is clear that the elections won't take place on April 24, but we are still assessing the election machinery as we make decisions about the way forward," the head of a newly appointed electoral council, Leopold Berlanger, told Reuters. Downgrading to 0%. I feel this prediction has been resolved, the Electoral council head has said it won't happen on the due date and has refused to give an actual due date.
No more information. But the situation still seems unstable and the election has delayed twice.

Due to past violent events against the government it seems that Haiti is incredibly unsure and disorganized when it comes to their election. I don't believe that they will be able to complete a successful election until their citizens are stable, and I don't believe that that has happened yet, therefore I don't feel that the scheduled election for April 24 will occur.

The government is very unstable and it does not seem like they are at all set up to hold such an election. Also, much of the news circulating around this issue seems to be heavily in favor of it not happening.

The Haitian government is already serverely unstable, stricken with extreme poverty, famine, and poor living standards for a significant amount of the population. Additionally, there are no rumors or candidates who would last in leading the opposition.

A broken political system coupled with violent protesters does not make for an organized run-off. I would make my prediction percentage lower but like a previous comment said there are certain variables that could change things.

I was going to put 1% but it looks like even Moise (http://www.miamiherald.com/opinion/op-ed/article71435012.html) and Berlanger (head of CEP) don't think April 24th will work. And given they have just approved the terms for a Verification Commission (http://www.haitilibre.com/en/news-17190-haiti-elections-verification-commission-terms-of-reference-approved-and-signed.html) and the time frame involved, it all suggests less than 0.5%.
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and gjp consensus.
After being postponed twice already the election has been declared postponed again per the miami herald. http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/haiti/article56092280.html

Right now, all signs point to a broken election process in Haiti which will lead to another delay in the run-off presidential vote. Because this event is fairly close, I feel comfortable placing the likelihood at such a low number. Specifically, the new head of elections was quoted as saying: "'It is clear that the elections won't take place on April 24, but we are still assessing the election machinery as we make decisions about the way forward,' the head of a newly appointed electoral council, Leopold Berlanger, told Reuters."

Haiti will not meet a deadline to complete its presidential election by April 24, the top election official said on Thursday, without giving a new date to hold the already delayed vote in the impoverished Caribbean country.
Plus Ã§a change, plus c'est la meme chose...
"Haiti will not meet a deadline to complete its presidential election by April 24, the top election official said on Thursday"

I am forecasting based on the general news reports and gjp consensus.

It’s not yet official, but the head of Haiti’s newly revamped Provisional Electoral Council made it clear Tuesday that the country’s repeatedly postponed final round, scheduled for the last Sunday of this month, won’t happen that day.
Well that's enough time for whoever is taking control of the system to have organised themselves into a legitimate looking body

The United States is pressing for fair and non-violent elections, but does not have a lot of sway with the population or the people in power. Everyone else is interested in waiting. People on the ground seem to be unofficially declaring the event DOA too.
Haiti's leading presidential candidate calls for the elections to happen on time. http://www.miamiherald.com/opinion/op-ed/article71435012.html
This past Tuesday, president of electoral court said that the scheduled elections would not be possible.

The situation is uncertain since January. the election have been schedule for the 24 april. However the president of provisional electoral council have said this tuesday that it won't be possible.  Haiti is really in the urgence to have election but they cannot have election where every post are contested.

I think the state of permanent revolution in Haiti is more capable of establishing national communism than it is of sustaining a true democracy. Too much money is to be made shaving dollars off of foreign aid for any election to go through cleanly. If elections are held, expect them to be fabricated or at least messy.
They postponed but the US wants it to happen, sheesh

No progress has been made on that front.

According to the news, the head of Haiti’s Provisional Electoral Council has already made clear that the run-off election scheduled for the last Sunday of this month, won’t happen.

U.S financial interest in Haitian government may encourage strong democracy however Haiti doesn't currently have a legitimate legal system to sort our electoral fraud which I think will make run-off elections difficult.

Totally uneducated guess based on the articles but they might fear US withdrawing financial support to help with future election process.

http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/haiti/article70385237.html
Suspicions of voting irregularities in the first round of the elections seem to be the primary reason Hatians want the second round delayed.  US, and others may be undermining their credibility, as Kerry puts pressure on holding elections without investigation of the allegations.
If they are held but declared invalid and forced to be held again, what happens with the resolution of this question?

While the international community supports an election as scheduled, it is highly unlikely given the logistics. Even the head of the Provisional Election Committee says that it will not occur on April 24. ( http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/haiti/article70110512.html )

Can't find a better place to leave new info on the Spanish negotiations ( wish I could bump up the C and P option a bit).

Presidential runoffs twice delayed.More than half of the 140 municipal elections in dispute"
http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/haiti/article70110512.html
It doesn't seem technically feasible to hold the run-offs on 24 April, and there are political obstacles as well. Will revisit after some consensus is established.
It's Haiti. The place is a completely dysfunctional dump.

1) They're scheduled until they're not, even if comments by local officials have suggested otherwise.
2) If you were the leading candidate, wouldn't you want to hold broken elections as soon as possible? There is a powerful political faction pushing for this to happen on schedule. The process problems are a feature, not a bug.
3) Delaying these run-offs leads to more questions about the constitutionality of the interim government. It's not as easy as simply delaying them.
4) The question only asks about run-off presidential elections, not the full run-off of all the legislative and municipal seats that are still outstanding.
@Raisinville link and history of unpredictable Haitian politics.

It's not official, but head of the Provisional Election Committee says it isn't going to happen.
http://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/americas/haiti/article70110512.html
Elections are costly.  No Haitian action without OPM to foot the bills.

While Haiti and the "nine-member Provisional Electoral Council ratified Wednesday is tasked with concluding an electoral cycle by holding a runoff to elect a president and the final members of parliament," there is no conclusive evidence that an election for April 24 is schedule or confirmed by NGOs monitoring international elections.   @cdob63 also indicates that the electorate in Haiti does not seem to think that the run-off election will take place.  There are additional indications that the Haitian parliament " rejected a program submitted by Prime Minister Fritz Jean, lawmakers said, throwing up a new hurdle as the politically volatile country struggles to meet deadlines to transfer power from an interim to an elected government."
Nobody there seems to think so.

Here is a pretty good "man on the ground" report.  The writer seems pessimistic given the logistics and the local population sense of the situation,  but apparently the international community would really like the elections to proceed on time.  Seems to hinge on the establishment of a "verification commission"
they dont have money, agreement on how to proceed, or infrastructure to get it done by the date, if what I have read is to be believed.
